topic.name: Photography (Artistic & Technical)
topic.sub_subject_name: Art History, Aesthetic Philosophy & Christian Worldview
topic.description: 13-year academic progression (K-12) for Photography (Artistic & Technical) in Fine Arts

objectives.objective_text: Identify the shutter button.
Identify overexposure (too bright).
Identify the background.
Identify that some pictures are tricks.
Name 'Photoshop' as a tool.
Identify deepfakes (video tricks).
Identify old black and white photos.
Name a camera that uses film.
Identify a Daguerreotype (shiny metal picture).
Identify where the sun is.
Identify backlighting (silhouette).
Identify the difference between posed and candid.
Identify brightness.
Recall that we need light to take pictures.
Observe that moving closer changes the picture.
Recall that we should tell the truth.
Observe a cartoon mixed with a real photo.
Recall that photos used to take a long time.
Observe a polaroid.
Recall that inside is darker than outside.
Observe shadows.
Hold the camera steady with two hands.
Turn the flash on and off.
Summarize Focus (making it clear vs. blurry).
Explain Zoom (near vs. far).
Use scene modes (Sports, Night).
Explain ISO and digital noise.
Defend the choice of settings for artistic intent.
Put the subject in the middle.
Don't cut off heads or feet.
Summarize the 'Rule of Thirds'.
Explain 'Leading Lines' (roads, fences).
Frame a subject using a window or tree.
Explain the figure-ground relationship.
Defend the psychological impact of framing.
Summarize why changing a news photo is bad.
Explain that magazine covers are often changed.
Explain digital watermarking.
Defend truth in photojournalism.
Summarize the Camera Obscura (dark room).
Explain how film needs light to work.
Explain the Cyanotype (sun print).
Defend the aesthetic value of film grain.
Stand so the sun is behind the camera.
Summarize why noon sun makes 'raccoon eyes'.
Explain how a white board (reflector) bounces light.
Explain the inverse square law (intro).
Defend the use of artificial light to shape reality.
Take a picture of a friend's face.
Take a picture of a big tree or hill.
Take a picture of a tiny bug.
Smile for the camera.
Summarize how to make a person look good (don't squint).
Explain the Horizon Line (keep it straight).
Capture a flower up close (Macro).
Explain focus stacking for macro.
Defend the dignity of the subject (Imago Dei).
Pick a filter (black and white).
Crop a picture to remove messy edges.
Rotate a picture if it is sideways.
Summarize contrast and saturation.
Explain why we edit photos (to make them look like real life).
Straighten a crooked horizon.
Remove a spot (red eye).
Explain the difference between JPEG and RAW.
Defend the 'integrity of the pixel' vs. manipulation.
Analyze the Exposure Triangle.
Interpret Aperture (f-stop) and Depth of Field.
Connect Shutter Speed to motion blur or freezing.
Compare a high angle vs. low angle.
Analyze the Golden Ratio in photography.
Interpret symmetry vs. asymmetry.
Connect negative space to isolation or peace.
Compare a filtered face with a real face.
Analyze the impact of airbrushing on self-esteem.
Interpret the journalistic code of ethics.
Connect AI generation to copyright issues.
Compare digital cameras with film cameras.
Analyze the chemical process of the darkroom.
Interpret the impact of photography on painting (Impressionism).
Connect the Kodak Brownie to mass photography.
Compare soft light (cloudy) vs. hard light (sunny).
Analyze Three-Point Lighting (Key, Fill, Back).
Interpret the color temperature of light (Kelvin).
Connect window light to Rembrandt lighting.
Analyze lens choice for portraits (85mm vs wide).
Interpret the 'Golden Hour' for landscapes.
Connect eye contact to connection.
Analyze the histogram levels.
Interpret Non-Destructive editing.
Connect shadow recovery to dynamic range.
Evaluate the histogram.
Evaluate the visual weight of elements.
Evaluate the theological implications of 'bearing false witness' visually.
Evaluate the archival stability of digital vs. analog.
Evaluate the mood created by High Key vs. Low Key.
Evaluate the use of hyper-focal distance in landscapes.
Evaluate the ethics of retouching (body image).
Construct a perfectly exposed image in Manual Mode.
Synthesize the relationship between sensor size and focal length.
Construct a composition that intentionally breaks rules.
Synthesize texture, pattern, and color in composition.
Construct a policy for ethical image use.
Synthesize artistic license with moral responsibility.
Construct an alternative process print (e.g., Cyanotype).
Synthesize the history of photography with modern practice.
Construct a studio lighting setup.
Synthesize flash photography with ambient light.
Construct a conceptual portrait series.
Synthesize environment and subject in environmental portraiture.
Construct a cohesive color grade for a series.
Synthesize frequency separation for skin retouching.
